review.title: CITlab ARGUS for historical handwritten documents
review.abstract: We describe CITlab's recognition system for the HTRtS competition attached to the 13. International Conference on Document Analysis and Recognition, ICDAR 2015. The task comprises the recognition of historical handwritten documents. The core algorithms of our system are based on multi-dimensional recurrent neural networks (MDRNN) and connectionist temporal classification (CTC). The software modules behind that as well as the basic utility technologies are essentially powered by PLANET's ARGUS framework for intelligent text recognition and image processing.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 5.08 412v 1 [cs.C V] 26 May 201 6CITlab ARGUS for historicalhandwritten documents Description of CITlab's System for the HTRtS 2015 Task: Handwritten Text Recognition on the tranScriptorium DatasetGundram Leifert Tobias Strauß Tobias GrüningRoger Labahn, 15 April 2015We describe CITlab's recognition system for the HTRtS competition as part of the 13th International Conference on Document Analysis and Recognition, ICDAR 2015. The task includes the recognition of historical handwritten documents. The core algorithms of our system are based on multidimensional, recurrent neural networks (MDRNN) and connectionist time classification (CTC). The underlying software modules and the basic auxiliary technologies are mainly driven by PLANET's ARGUS framework for intelligent text recognition and image processing.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The International Conference on Document Analysis and Recognition, ICDAR 20151, is organizing a number of competitions in this area. HTRtS2 includes a task of word recognition for segmented historical documents, see [SRTV14] for all further details. This data consists of page images from the Bentham Collection, a well-known transScriptorium project dataset.Our neural networks were previously used in the context of the OpenHaRT 2013 international handwriting competition in the appendix to the ICDAR 2013 conference, see [LLG13].

sections.heading: 2 Short Description
sections.text: Note 1. This brief description is intended for the information of the organisers of the HTRtS-2015. Here we also explain the abbreviations used in submitting the recognition results of CITlab ARGUS on the web form. Please quote this now as: private communication, extended version to be published after ICDAR 2015. This draft is provisional in the sense that it will be extended to a full paper version. It will be published after the ICDAR 2015 conference, when the official final results of the evaluation will be published.

sections.heading: 2.1 Overview
sections.text: Overall, CITlab delivers the recognition / transcription results of 14 moderately different systems. Although they are mainly based on our traditional recurring neural network-based recognition engine ARGUS, the 14 variations result from the combination of 2 training programs, trn-1 / trn-2, with 7 decoding programs, dec-BP / dec-CE / dec-DM and2http: / / transcriptorium.eu / ~ htrcontest 3http: / / www.citlab.uni-rostock.de 4http: / / www.planet.dedering of the respective labels, reflecting both the increasing complexity of the programs and the expected improved quality of the handwritten text recognition task.

sections.heading: 2.2 Basic Scheme
sections.text: For the general approach, we can briefly refer to earlier CITlab system descriptions [LLS13, LGSL14, SGLL14], as the overall scheme has not changed substantially.

sections.heading: 2.3 Preprocessing
sections.text: We worked on line polygon images, see 2.4.1 for further explanation of the data. First, certain standard pre-processing routines were used, i.e. • Image normalization: contrast, size; • Write normalization: line curvature, stroke inclination, script inclination. Then, images were further standardized by CITlab's proprietary write normalization, ensuring a fixed image height of 96 pixels, with the body of the font suitably stretched in and out to cover the essential central part of the line image. Finally, these were the input images for subsequent processing with Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN).

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Recurrent Neural Network
sections.text: The resulting line images have been fed into the first core component of the engine, which we call the Sequence Processing Recurrent Neural Network (SPRNN). Note that we have complete line images with no further segmentation. The output of the SPRNN then consists of a certain number of vectors. This number is related to the line length, because each vector contains information about a certain image position. Specifically, the entries are understood to estimate the probabilities of each alphabet character at the position under consideration. Also, note that for HTRtS-2015 we worked with the alphabet that contains • all digits, lowercase letters and uppercase letters of the standard Latin alphabet, which are then used for decoding. Also, note that for HTRtS-2015 we worked with the alphabet that contains • all digits, lowercase letters and uppercase letters of the standard Latin alphabet\ _

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Training Data
sections.text: trn-1 consists of all 1stBatch line polygons, i.e. images of 10 491 line polygons from 433 page. trn-2 contains trn-1 and all 2ndBatch page images: an additional 313 pages for which the line polygons were not available. trn-2 uses proprietary CITlab tools to extract a total of 3,968 additional line polygons, s.t. trn-2 finally contained 14,479 training samples. It is particularly noteworthy that we did not use the line images themselves from the data provided in HTRtS-2015, because they cover more distortions between adjacent text lines.

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Network Training
sections.text: In both training programs, different networks were trained in a similar way: the number of training periods varied slightly between 50 and 60, and the decrease in learning rates was chosen accordingly. Furthermore, different experiments differed in certain hyperparameters (number of neurons, subsampling rate) and random selections of baseline weights, which were then optimized by gradient descent procedures. Finally, from a larger number of experiments, 10 networks were selected, monitoring training success on the basis of a validation dataset selected from the available training data due to the lack of separate data, see 2.4.1.
